meta_data.title: TDNetGen: Predicting Network Resilience with Generative Augmentation
meta_data.abstract: In this work, we propose an effective framework, TDNetGen, for complex network resilience prediction. It not only addresses the problem in a data-driven manner without prior knowledge about ground-truth dynamics but also solves the labeled data sparsity problem with the generative augmentation of jointly modeling network topology and dynamics. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of TDNetGen and also highlight its robustness within less labeled data and dynamics information conditions. The methodology introduced in this paper provides a novel perspective for improving resilience prediction through data augmentation, leveraging the untapped potential of unlabeled data to enhance the learning process.

relate work.related papers: Gao et al., propose to reduce the dimension of complex networks to single-parameter systems based on mean-field theory. Laurence et al., perform dimension reduction based on spectral graph theory.
relate work.comparisons with related methods: TDNetGen extends the capabilities of existing methods by integrating both topology and dynamics in its predictive framework. Comparatively, it offers enhanced robustness against data sparsity and utilizes a generative augmentation approach to improve predictive performance.

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: This paper presents TDNetGen, a novel framework employing generative augmentation for predicting network resilience. By integrating neural models that capture both the topology and dynamic evolution of networks, it addresses label scarcity and significantly enhances prediction accuracy.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To provide accurate resilience prediction in complex network systems using minimal labeled data through a novel data augmentation strategy.
high_level_summary.research challenge: The principal challenge is predicting network resilience amidst limited labeled data and complex interactions between topology and dynamics.
high_level_summary.method summary: The method involves generative augmentation using Diffusion Models to simulate topology and dynamics, thus augmenting training data. A resilience predictor integrates GNN and Transformer models for classification.
high_level_summary.conclusion: TDNetGen provides a robust solution to network resilience prediction, outperforming traditional methods by leveraging unlabeled data and generative techniques.

Method.description: TDNetGen leverages neural networks to predict network resilience by modeling both topology and dynamics of networks. It uses a data-driven approach without requiring comprehensive prior knowledge of the system's dynamics.
Method.problem formultaion: Predicting network resilience when labels are sparse, focusing on the interplay between network topology and dynamics.
Method.model: The framework uses a Graph Convolutional Network (GCN) based topology encoder and a Transformer-based trajectory encoder to predict resilience from network features.
Method.complexity: TDNetGen operates with a time complexity of O(N^2), making it scalable for large graph structures.
Method.algorithm step: Generative augmentation involves two steps: (1) Topology generation, (2) Dynamics simulation. Followed by Resilience Prediction using GNN and Transformer for classification.

Experiments.setup: Experiments are conducted to answer research questions regarding performance, design effectiveness, and application under limited data scenarios.
Experiments.hyperparameters: Guidance intensity Î» = 2000; Adam optimizer for model training.
Experiments.results: TDNetGen significantly outperforms baseline models on several datasets, achieving up to 95% accuracy in network resilience prediction even in label scarce conditions.
Experiments.analysis: The method consistently improves prediction accuracy by modeling the joint distribution of topology and dynamics, demonstrating robustness without node state data.
Experiments.ablation study: Ablation studies detail the contribution of each component, revealing the importance of classifier guidance and the refinement process in enhancing predictive accuracy.

conclusion.summary: The study successfully introduces a novel framework, TDNetGen, for leveraging generative augmentation to improve prediction of resilience in complex networks under limited labeled data conditions. This work highlights the potential of integrating topology and dynamics augmentation in improving predictive tasks across various domains.
conclusion.future work: Future research may focus on extending TDNetGen's applicability to other domains and further optimizing the generative augmentation processes.
